At-a-Glance: Varroa destructor is the pivotal health pressure on managed honey bees. Reliable, repeatable monitoring guides timely treatment decisions and prevents virus cascades.
Why it Matters: Untreated or undetected varroa loads drive DWV and other virus issues leading to winter losses.
Monitoring replaces guesswork with thresholds that trigger action at the right time.
Good data lets you compare apiaries, genetics, and interventions over seasons.
Objectives: Adopt one primary quantitative method and stick to it for comparability.
Sample at consistent times: pre-season, mid-season, post-harvest, and pre-winter.
Record results per colony and aggregate at yard level.
What Good Looks Like: Consistent sampling method and volume (e.g., 300 bees) with clean equipment.
Thresholds agreed in advance, linked to specific actions.
Results logged immediately with date, colony ID, brood status, and weather notes.
Step-by-Step: 1) Choose method: alcohol wash (gold standard), sugar roll (non-lethal), or natural mite drop via sticky board.
2) Sampling: shake nurse bees from brood frames into a tub, scoop ~300 bees (half cup).
3) Alcohol wash: submerge bees in isopropyl alcohol, agitate 60 seconds, count dislodged mites.
4) Sugar roll: coat bees with powdered sugar, shake through a mesh, count mites in tray, then return bees.
5) Sticky boards: place under screened bottom for 24–72 hours, count daily drops, interpret with caution.
6) Calculate infestation: mites per 300 bees -> percentage infestation.
7) Decide: compare against seasonal thresholds and act per plan.
Seasonality & Climate: Spring: baseline checks before major brood expansion.
Summer: monitor during flows and immediately post-harvest.
Autumn: crucial check before winter bees are raised.
Winter: natural drop can inform but is less precise.
Data & Thresholds: Alcohol/sugar: ≥3 percent mid-season typically triggers treatment in many regions.
Autumn thresholds are lower because winter bee health is at stake (often 1–2 percent).
Natural drop: interpretation varies with brood status; use alongside direct sampling.
Diagnostics & Decision Tree: Symptom: Deformed wings present -> Immediate quantitative test -> If over threshold, treat now.
Symptom: Spotty brood and dwindling -> Test 2 methods to confirm -> Treat and reassess in 14 days.
Symptom: High natural drop but low wash -> Check brood levels and sampling quality -> Repeat with fresh sample.
Common Pitfalls: Inconsistent sample size leading to misleading percentages.
Sampling foragers instead of nurses from brood frames.
Relying only on sticky boards during heavy brood periods.
Tools & Techniques: Labeled sampling jars, mesh lids, isopropyl alcohol, sieves, white trays.
Powdered sugar, measuring scoop, timer, notebook or digital log.
Screened bottoms and sticky boards with food-grade oil.
Safety & Compliance: Handle alcohol away from flames; dispose responsibly.
Minimise bee losses by competent technique and swift handling.
Communications: Explain to stakeholders why monitoring frequency increases before winter.
Further Reading: USDA and provincial apiculture notes comparing methods.
Notes: Use the same jar and scoop each time for repeatability. Calibrate your bee volume once with a count sample.
